node.text:
On the 18th of July, birthday of Canadian composer and acoustic ecologist R. Murray Schafer, we celebrate #WorldListeningDay. It is a day to really listen – what does the world sound like with or without the noises that are imposed on us by technology, industry, and our own selves? 

In celebration of soundscape in Zion, we offer a short video highlighting some of the evening murmurings you may hear if you take a stroll at sunset or camp under the stars. Of course, these are not the only sounds we experience and contribute to. The earth is never silent, however we can all do our part to reduce unnecessary volume by hiking with headphones rather than speakers (or simply the music of the park), keep conversations quiet, and enjoy experiences that may be very different from our day to day lives. 

What is the soundscape like where you live? Our mornings are punctuated with rustling leaves as wind blows down the canyon, while afternoons are dominated by rumbling shuttle buses, people chatting, and gravel and sand scrunching underfoot. Depending on the time of day or year that you visit, you’ll have a unique auditory experience! 

NPS Video/ Montage of five short videos of different areas of the park, overlaid with natural sounds. First, a small waterfall trickles into a pool. Next, the video pans across the cliffs including and around Angels Landing and the Great White Throne with various bird calls. The focus shifts to the shallow river with cliffs in the background, and the trickling of the river can be heard. Next, we head up the West Rim trail to see a small chipmunk scurry away, panning up along the cliffs, leaving the trail behind. Lastly, we find ourselves at Scout Lookout, overlooking the floor of the canyon from high above. The video ends by panning up to a partly cloudy periwinkle and pink sunset.

node.text:
Join Ranger Kristina as she teaches you how some lizards in Zion National Park avoid becoming lunch! In this video, we talk about chuckwalla, desert spiny lizards, western whiptails, greater short horned lizards, and plateau lizards.

Visit the park website to learn more about reptiles here: https://www.nps.gov/zion/learn/nature/reptiles.htm

node.text:
"Piglet noticed that even though he had a very small heart, it could hold a rather large amount of gratitude." — A.A. Milne

What are you thankful for? Share in the comments! 

We are thankful for the healing power of nature. Here is a daily dose from Zion! Settle into this extended scene in Zion Canyon, filmed in Spring of 2020. 

This series of videos gives people a chance to spend a few peaceful minutes in the park. In this video, imagine sitting under the cottonwood trees on the floor of Zion Canyon and looking up at the canyon walls around you. The red sandstone peak in the scene is named Mount Spry and can be seen near Canyon Junction.
NPS Video

Join Ranger Amy as she describes some interesting items in the park collections. This is part one of a three part series. This episode will feature items from prehistoric and pioneer history.

For more information, visit our website.
Zion Human History Museum webpage: https://www.nps.gov/zion/learn/historyculture/zion-human-history-museum.htm

Search for historic Zion images:
https://npgallery.nps.gov/zion

More details about the featured Yucca Sandal:
https://www.nps.gov/zion/learn/historyculture/yucca-sandal.htm

NPS Video

node.text:
Lots of people hope to see wildlife when they visit a national park. Ranger Daniel explains ways for us to stay safe and protect the wildlife while visiting Zion. 

More information is on our website: https://www.nps.gov/.../nature/wildlife-viewing-safety.htm

NPS Video
#keepwildlifewild

node.text:
Learn about Mexican spotted owls and the wildlife surveys that park biologists use to monitor the population. Ranger Mark will take you on location, with a special appearance by an actual owl!

For more information about Mexican spotted owls, check out these links -

NPS website: https://www.nps.gov/articles/mexican-spotted-owl.htm

Listen to a recording of the owl call at the Cornell Lab of Ornithology: https://www.allaboutbirds.org/guide/Spotted_Owl/overview

NPS Video

node.title: Mexican Spotted Owls with Ranger Mark

node.text:
Need a break? Settle into this extended scene in Zion Canyon. This video gives people a chance to spend a few peaceful minutes in the park. In this video, imagine sitting under the cottonwood trees on the floor of Zion Canyon and looking up at the canyon walls around you. The ambient noise includes light breezes and birdsong.
NPS Video

node.text:
About a month ago, we asked you for questions... tune in for the answers! Brought to you by the rangers at Zion National Park

Featuring:
0:15 What is a day in the life of a ranger like?
1:40 How many visitors get bitten by snakes each year and how can you avoid having any kind of snake encounter?
3:03 What is the longest time that a park ranger has worked at Zion?
3:43 How do you become a ranger?
4:27 What sort of wildflowers bloom during the spring in Zion?
5:12 What is the tallest peak is in Zion?
5:53 What kind of animals live in the park?
8:05 What’s the best season or time of year to visit the park?
9:00 What time of year is the best to hike the Narrows?
11:46 What is your favorite part of being a ranger?
12:36 What is the coolest rock formation found in the park?

Ask us more questions in the comments!

Do you need a break? Settle into this extended scene in Zion Canyon. This video gives you a chance to spend a few peaceful minutes in the park. In this video, imagine sitting under the cottonwood trees on the floor of Zion Canyon and looking up at the canyon walls around you. The red sandstone peak in the scene is named Mount Moroni and can be seen near the Court of the Patriarchs at shuttle stop #4. The video contains only ambient noise, light breezes and birdsong.

NPS Video

Buffalo Soldier troopers in formation, ready for inspection in Cuba.
Photo courtesy (United States Army)

node.text:
#OnthisDay: 155 years ago on July 28, 1866, four Black regiments were formed: the 9th and 10th Cavalry Regiments, and  20th and 25th Infantry Regiments. Following the formation, these African-American soldiers were dispatched to the west to fight in the Indian Wars. The regiments eventually received the name Buffalo Soldiers by the Cheyenne and other Plains Indians due to the resemblance between their dark, curly hair and the matted cushion between the horns of the buffalo.

These men would go on to become some of the first National Park park rangers and backcountry rangers, patrolling parts of the West. Charles Young served as the acting military superintendent of Sequoia National Park in 1903. Although his time as superintendent was brief, it was revolutionary. Young is considered by some to be the first African-American superintendent of a National Park. 

Even though the Buffalo Soldiers wore the uniform of the U.S. Army, their ethnicity combined with the racial prejudice of the time made the performance of their duties quite challenging. In the early 1900s, African-Americans were routinely abused, or even killed, for the slightest perceived offense. They occupied one of the lowest rungs of the social ladder; a fact which served to undercut the authority of any black man who served in any position of power. Their noteworthy accomplishments were made despite the added burden of racism.

To learn more about the many accomplishments of these men, visit www.nps.gov/subjects/buffalosoldiers/index.htm

#BuffaloSoldiers #FirstRangers #NPSHistory #BlackHistory

node.text:
Look before you leap! Actually, don’t physically ‘leap’ at all. A common incident in Zion National Park occurs when visitors jump while out on hikes or canyoneering. The injuries that result from jumping from your last rappel while canyoneering or on a hike such as the Narrows, could likely result in a Search and Rescue. When visiting Zion, keep in mind your safety is your responsibility. Our Search and Rescue team responds to over 250 incidents every year. Here are some safety tips to follow so you can make sure you’re not part of that statistic:

Carry enough water - a gallon of water per person per day, and drink it!
Eat salty snacks - drinking fluids while not eating can lead to a potentially dangerous condition of low blood salt
Avoid cliff edges and stay on trail - even though you think that selfie will be worth it, I can promise you it’s not. 

Check the weather before you hike! We are in our monsoon season which means the potential of flash floods is elevated. You can make sure that flash floods are not expected for the day by checking in with the Rangers at the Visitor Center or by visiting weather.gov

Following basic safety precautions will mean a more enjoyable adventure in Zion. 

#RecreateResponsibly #PlanLikeAParkRanger

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Zion National Park on July 26, 2021. May be an image of 2 people and people standing.

node.text:
This hot weather has us wishing we could #throwback to a cooler time, like the 2002 Salt Lake Olympic Torch Relay! On February 4th, 2002, torchbearers carried the Olympic flame through Zion National Park, on its way to the 2002 Salt Lake City winter Olympics. The torch was carried over 13,500 miles from Atlanta, Georiga to Salt Lake City, Utah, a trip that was shared by more than 11,500 different torchbearers. Eleven of those torchbearers carried the torch in Zion, covering about 2.2 miles, before it continued its final leg of the journey to Salt Lake. 

To read more about the torch’s journey through Utah, check out: https://www.nps.gov/articles/arch-olympic-torch.htm

Are you watching the Olympics this year? 

#Olympics #FindYourPark #EncuentraTuParque

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Zion National Park on July 25, 2021. May be a closeup of nature and tree.

node.text:
As one of the most common trees in the park , our Utah Junipers (Juniperus osterosperma) are often overlooked, but they can hold some surprises!

Looking closely at the branch tips of some junipers, you may notice some bizarre, spiky growths that are often clustered together. Have aliens come to Zion?

Not quite - these odd growths are actually galls! A gall is a growth created by a plant in response to a parasite - most commonly, an insect laying its eggs in the plant. In this case, the insect responsible is a tiny midge in the genus Walshomyia. Since the gall is formed by the plant, not the insect, it's built out of a modified version of the plant's tissues. In this case, the spines that form these galls are just elongated versions of the juniper's typical scale-like leaves. 

Galls come in many different shapes and sizes! Have you seen these or any other types of galls in the park?

#FindYourPark #EncuentraTuParque

node.text:
We’re nearing the end of #LatinoConservationWeek! Meet Ranger Celeste, and hear about why she likes working for the park. 

English transcript: Hi, my name is Celeste Moran and I am a ranger in Zion National Park. I work in canyon bus operations, which involves communicating with visitors and making sure everyone is prepared to climb this beautiful canyon. Because I speak with so many visitors, I consider my skills to communicate in Spanish to be very important, since that allows me to be able to speak to everyone and make everyone feel welcome in the park. Diversity is important because National Parks were established for all to enjoy. The diversity of rangers and visitors can contribute to providing a more positive experience to all National Parks with representation.

#EncuentraTuParque #FindYourPark

node.text:
“Thunder only happens when it’s raining” Well… not really. Thunder can occur without rain, but it never happens without lightning 🌩️

This monsoon season, Zion has been experiencing a series of thunderstorms that have resulted in some beautiful lightshows. Though it can be fun to watch, lightning can be very dangerous. 

Lightning causes an average of 55-60 fatalities and 400 injuries each year in the U.S. alone.  More than 70% of lightning fatalities occur in June, July, and August and are most common in afternoons and evenings. Anyone who is outside during a thunderstorm is at risk. A majority of victims struck by lightning were heading to a safe place but waited too long before seeking shelter. Lighting can strike 10 - 15 miles away from a thunderstorm, so when thunder roars, go indoors! 

If you are outdoors and hear thunder, get to a safe location like inside a building or inside a metal vehicle with a hard metal top and windows closed. If you are outside with no safe shelter nearby, immediately get off elevated areas, never lie flat on the ground, never shelter under an isolated tree, never use a cliff or overhang as shelter, avoid concrete, and stay away from open water sources.

When planning your trip always check the weather forecast before doing any outdoor activities. If the forecast calls for a thunderstorm, make sure to have a backup plan. According to the National Weather Service, there are four main factors that contribute to lightning fatalities: unwillingness to cancel or postpone activities, unaware of approaching or developing storms, vulnerability of the activity, inability and/or unwillingness to get to a safe place quickly and stay there until the thunderstorm has passed.

Remember, your safety is your responsibility.

To learn more, visit www.cdc.gov/disasters/lightning/safetytips.html

#RecreateResponsibly 
NPS Video: A short video of lightning striking above the West Temple.

node.text:
A lot of work goes on behind the scenes to keep our national parks safe, sustainable, and beautiful. Research permitting, NEPA applications, and reviewing land use changes are challenging and important work, and we’re grateful to have passionate people like Shauna Ertolacci who are dedicated to protecting wildlife and maintaining the world’s natural beauty. Check out Shauna’s story – you might be surprised to learn it started by studying neotropical primates in Ecuador! #DareToImagine #WhatWeDoWednesdays

https://www.nps.gov/articles/000/dtiertolacci.htm

📷NPS Illustration/K.Bailey

node.text:
Is that a smoke detector I hear? 

Nope! Often confused for a bird call or a blues smoke detector, this chirping noise is actually produced by one of Zion’s most commonly seen animals: the rock squirrel (Spermophilus variegatus). This call is often used to alert other squirrels in the area of predators or other potential danger. 

Remember, even though they look cute, they are still wild animals. Help keep wildlife wild by not feeding them and keeping your distance, and not just for their sake - bites and scratches from squirrels can transmit some nasty bacteria and diseases to humans. 

#WildlifeWednesday #RecreateResponsibly

NPS video/ A brown and grey rock squirrel vocalizes from the top branch of a tree.

node.text:
Preventative drainage clearing will begin on July 26, 2021 with an anticipated end date in August 2021. On June 29, 2021 the park experienced a flash flood and this drainage clearing is a proactive approach for maintenance needed during the monsoon season. 

Utah State Route 9 (SR-9) through Zion National Park will be closing nightly from 10:00 PM MDT until 6:00 AM MDT starting July 26, 2021. During the scheduled maintenance, a full closure to ALL vehicle traffic will be implemented Monday through Thursday from 10:00PM MDT to 6:00 AM MDT. 

No construction is scheduled to occur over the weekends from Friday 6:00 AM MDT to Monday 10:00 PM MDT. Proceeding with maintenance and full closures at night is anticipated to decrease traffic congestion, reduce visitor impacts, as well as facilitate safe and efficient working environment for the road maintenance operating heavy equipment. 

Alternate east and west routes are available via Highway 59 from Hurricane, Utah to Fredonia, Arizona and Highway 14 from Cedar City, Utah to Long Valley Junction and Highway 89. 

https://bit.ly/3z9HrOW

node.accessibility_caption: Biologist rappelling hundreds of feet down to enter the condor nest.

node.text:
Did you know that there are California condors in Zion? California condors are the largest flying land birds in North America with a wingspan of up to 9.5 feet (3 meters) and we have a pair that has successfully nested right here the park!

Back in November of 2020, Zion’s Vertical Habitat Specialist took a break from monitoring cliff roosting bats to get up close and personal with the condor nest. Due to the time it takes for condor parents to raise their chick, they only nest every other year which allowed a perfect window of time to do a little nest exploration and clean up while the birds were away. 

One of the many threats that condors face, is the ingestion of microtrash, which was unfortunately found inside of the nest along with many larger pieces of trash. Many visitors drop trash from the popular Angels Landing trail, which is right near the condor nest. Condors are very curious birds and can be attracted to the shine of a plastic water bottle or a pair of sunglasses and even bring it back to the nest and try to feed it to their chick which can easily be fatal as they are unable to digest it. 

Do your part to help protect these magnificent birds, and if you plan to visit Zion or hike Angels Landing, make sure your trash is disposed of properly and your items are secured so they do not end up in a condors nest!

 #LeaveNoTrace #RecreateResponsibly 

NPS Photos/Sierra Martin

node.accessibility_caption: Biologist rappelling hundreds of feet down to enter the condor nest.
Biologist standing inside the opening of the condor nest.
Trash that was removed from the condor nest. Trash includes a rusty can, a food wrapper, sunglasses, a bottle cap, and three different water bottles.

node.text:
As we continue #LatinoConservationWeek, meet Ranger Rendall, and learn more about what it means to be a Wilderness ranger!

English transcript: Hello! My name is Rendall Seely, I am a Wilderness Ranger in Zion National Park, a Leave No Trace Master Educator, and a bit of a dinosaur fanatic. 
Two of the main responsibilities that I have as a ranger are: issuing permits to visitors for backpacking, canyoneering, and hiking trips, and going on patrols into the Zion Wilderness. 
I help write the content that is published in our Wilderness Guide newspaper and informational handouts. I am also a web author for the park, helping assure that the Wilderness information you read on our park website is current and easy to navigate. 
Traveling into the Zion Wilderness, even on short trips, can be very challenging and requires careful planning before you begin. Your safety depends on your own good judgment, adequate preparation, and constant observation.

#EncuentraTuParque #FindYourPark

node.text:
On the 18th of July, birthday of Canadian composer and acoustic ecologist R. Murray Schafer, we celebrate #WorldListeningDay. It is a day to really listen – what does the world sound like with or without the noises that are imposed on us by technology, industry, and our own selves? 

In celebration of soundscape in Zion, we offer a short video highlighting some of the evening murmurings you may hear if you take a stroll at sunset or camp under the stars. Of course, these are not the only sounds we experience and contribute to. The earth is never silent, however we can all do our part to reduce unnecessary volume by hiking with headphones rather than speakers (or simply the music of the park), keep conversations quiet, and enjoy experiences that may be very different from our day to day lives. 

What is the soundscape like where you live? Our mornings are punctuated with rustling leaves as wind blows down the canyon, while afternoons are dominated by rumbling shuttle buses, people chatting, and gravel and sand scrunching underfoot. Depending on the time of day or year that you visit, you’ll have a unique auditory experience! 

NPS Video/ Montage of five short videos of different areas of the park, overlaid with natural sounds. First, a small waterfall trickles into a pool. Next, the video pans across the cliffs including and around Angels Landing and the Great White Throne with various bird calls. The focus shifts to the shallow river with cliffs in the background, and the trickling of the river can be heard. Next, we head up the West Rim trail to see a small chipmunk scurry away, panning up along the cliffs, leaving the trail behind. Lastly, we find ourselves at Scout Lookout, overlooking the floor of the canyon from high above. The video ends by panning up to a partly cloudy periwinkle and pink sunset.
